title: What's the idea behind the 4 chords that I can play many songs with? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s not at all uncommon for a rock, country, or pop song to have four main chords — or even fewer. Part of this is because it’s pretty easy to remember four chords. And it keeps the song accessible to average people… too many chords, and well, let’s let Lou Reed take this one: "One chord is fine. Two chords is pushing it. Three chords and you're into jazz." Especially if they’re 7th chords :-) But part of it’s the idea of a chord progression and the timing of music. Lots of popular songs are played in common time, also known as 4/4 time, four beats per measure, and usually like this: STRONG - weak - STRONG - weak as the beat emphasis. You can find other time signatures, but 4/4 dominates popular music. So your rate of chord changes — your harmonic rhythm — establishes an effective groove in the song, and it’s typically the case that I’m changing chords on the STRONG beat, thus, two chord changes per measure, to match the four full beats per measure. And creating a chord progression of four chords makes music much more interesting than using just two. However, even in three chord songs, it’s likely they’re following a four chord progression… just with two chords repeated. That’s not the end of it, though. Within every musical key you have seven major chords. But due to how we hear, due to what we’ve heard in the past (eg, our musical vocabulary), we just like certain chords changing into others, and find other chord to chord changes rather odd. In fact, Dave Carlton did an analysis of the chord changes in 1300 songs, and found some detailed and interesting statistics (I analyzed the chords of 1300 popular songs for patterns. This is what I found.). So you wind up with progressions within a key like I–V–vi–IV … which represents the first, fifth, sixth, and fourth cord in a key as a progression. There are plenty of other progressions, but this is a particularly popular one. How popular. The Axis of Awesome will demonstrate here:  Of course, there’s more to any popular song than just the chords. But there’s a fundamental thing to that… if I pick up a guitar and start playing, I’m strumming the chords and keeping the rhythm. I establish a foundation for a song on a single instrument. If I sing along, then we have a melody as well… and of course, that’s likely to be somewhat different, even when the songs all have the same chord patterns. And you progress from there to find other differences — some chord changes that are different, different lyrical structures, a solo in one, a bridge in another, etc. And of course, not all those featured were originally in the key of D.. so they’re going to sound a bit different, even on the one guitar, due to the different keys that might be used. So what determines the key? Sometimes its based on the main instrument — some keys are more difficult to play than others on a guitar. If you’re counting on a diatonic (one-key) instrument like a Harmonica, you need to have one made turned to the right key (you can actually get two keys on a Harmonica by playing cross-harp, and actually four, since there’s a minor and major key that contain the same notes, and more if you want to get aggressive about note bending/overblowing and remember when to do it… but I digress) . And often, you just like that key. I’ve written songs in one key or another, then played around with transposing, and often got a sound I just liked better. That’s really all there has to be to it. We all have a musical vocabularly, the parts of the language of music that we’ve learned by listening, maybe later by playing. Some things just sound right because they’re familiar. If you hear a slide guitar, you probably think “country”, if there are two guitars, a bass, and drums, it just might be a rock song., that kind of thing. Chord progressions are no different.

A lot of these answers are very interesting and imaginative. I wouldn’t take most of them very seriously, especially when they try and explain things in terms of music theory. First thing you should realize is that those chords don’t actually work for a lot of songs, most songs, in fact. Second thing to know, the “Four chords” video is actually a satire. It makes fun of the “If it works for them it’ll work for me” tendency among songwriters. Those people do copy each other. Note: To add to the humor, those wacky “Axis of Awesome” guys actually squeezed songs in that didn’t really use that chord progression. Comedy, after all, stretches the limits. Third thing: Following they idea of “Thing Two”(I feel like Dr. Suess here), at different times, there have been different chord progressions that have been used in this way. Doowop, for instance, used “I-vi-IV(or ii)V”(C-Am-F or Dm-G7) There was a run of about 50 years when every popular song ran through at least part of I-III7-VI7-II7-V7 (C-E7-A7-D7-G7) Reggae, particularly Bob Marley, favored vi-V(Am-G). Not every song, but at least 100 of them And don’t forget, that country music is defined as “Three Chords and the Truth” Fourth thing(and I could go all night). The first time I heard “Let It Be”, I thought “I love this! It sounds like a hymn!”(Even more than “Hey, Jude”). Macca knew this, because he stuck the “Mother Mary comes to me…” line in. And that’s the whole deal. We like it because it sounds familiar, because it is, or at least is like one of those diatonic major key melodies that we’ve been listening to in one form or another since Isaac Watt began gathering hymns. Fifth thing(I said I could just keep going): It’s familiarity, and not “music theory” that make this work for us. Other musical traditions use and reuse melodies that don’t use our scales, intervals, harmonies or meters. If you think there is something basic and universal about those old melodies and harmonies, listen to this Bulgarian women’s ensemble dig into those “dissonant” harmonies. Keep in mind that traditionally, at harvest time, women worked in small groups, singing and harmonizing on songs like this. And the groups tended to choose up based on singing rather than harvesting abilities.  Sixth thing: Just kidding…that all…
